items.name: HBASERESTSERVER_role_env_safety_valve

items.description: For advanced use only, key-value pairs (one on each line) to be inserted into a role's environment. Applies to configurations of this role except client configuration.

items.name: enable_alerts
items.displayName: Enable Health Alerts for this Role
items.description: When set, Cloudera Manager will send alerts when the health of this role reaches the threshold specified by the EventServer setting eventserver_health_events_alert_threshold

items.name: rm_memory_hard_limit
items.description: Hard memory limit to assign to this role, enforced by the Linux kernel. When the limit is reached, the kernel will reclaim pages charged to the process. If reclaiming fails, the kernel may kill the process. Both anonymous as well as page cache pages contribute to the limit. Use a value of -1 B to specify no limit. By default processes not managed by Cloudera Manager will have no limit.

items.name: rm_memory_soft_limit
items.description: Soft memory limit to assign to this role, enforced by the Linux kernel. When the limit is reached, the kernel will reclaim pages charged to the process if and only if the host is facing memory pressure. If reclaiming fails, the kernel may kill the process. Both anonymous as well as page cache pages contribute to the limit. Use a value of -1 B to specify no limit. By default processes not managed by Cloudera Manager will have no limit.

items.name: hbase_restserver_info_port
items.displayName: HBase REST Server Web UI Port
items.description: The port that HBase REST Server Web UI binds to.

items.name: rm_cpu_shares
items.description: Number of CPU shares to assign to this role. The greater the number of shares, the larger the share of the host's CPUs that will be given to this role when the host experiences CPU contention. Must be between 2 and 262144. Defaults to 1024 for processes not managed by Cloudera Manager.

items.name: process_auto_restart
items.description: When set, this role's process is automatically (and transparently) restarted in the event of an unexpected failure.

items.name: log_event_whitelist
items.displayName: Rules to Extract Events from Log Files
items.description:
This file contains the rules which govern how log messages are turned into events by the custom log4j appender that this role loads. It is in JSON format, and is composed of a list of rules. Every log message is evaluated against each of these rules in turn to decide whether or not to send an event for that message.

Each rule has some or all of the following fields:

  • alert - whether or not events generated from this rule should be promoted to alerts. A value of "true" will cause alerts to be generated. If not specified, the default is "false".
  • rate (mandatory) - the maximum number of log messages matching this rule that may be sent as events every minute. If more than rate matching log messages are received in a single minute, the extra messages are ignored. If rate is less than 0, the number of messages per minute is unlimited.
  • periodminutes - the number of minutes during which the publisher will only publish rate events or fewer. If not specified, the default is one minute
  • threshold - apply this rule only to messages with this log4j severity level or above. An example is "WARN" for warning level messages or higher.
  • content - match only those messages whose contents match this regular expression.
  • exceptiontype - match only those messages which are part of an exception message. The exception type must match this regular expression.

Example:{"alert": false, "rate": 10, "exceptiontype": "java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException"}

This rule will send events to Cloudera Manager for every StringIndexOutOfBoundsException, up to a maximum of 10 every minute.

items.name: oom_heap_dump_dir
items.description: Path to directory where heap dumps are generated when java.lang.OutOfMemoryError error is thrown. This directory is automatically created if it does not exist. If this directory already exists, role user must have write access to this directory. If this directory is shared among multiple roles, it should have 1777 permissions. The heap dump files are created with 600 permissions and are owned by the role user. The amount of free space in this directory should be greater than the maximum Java Process heap size configured for this role.

items.name: role_triggers
items.description:
The configured triggers for this role. This is a JSON formatted list of triggers. These triggers are evaluated as part as the health system. Every trigger expression is parsed, and if the trigger condition is met, the list of actions provided in the trigger expression is executed.

Each trigger has all of the following fields:

  • triggerName (mandatory) - The name of the trigger. This value must be unique for the specific role.
  • triggerExpression (mandatory) - A tsquery expression representing the trigger.
  • streamThreshold (optional) - The maximum number of streams that can satisfy a condition of a trigger before the condition fires. By default set to 0, and any stream returned causes the condition to fire.
  • enabled (optional) - By default set to 'true'. If set to 'false', the trigger will not be evaluated.
  • expressionEditorConfig (optional) - Metadata for the trigger editor. If present, the trigger should only be edited from the Edit Trigger page; editing the trigger here may lead to inconsistencies.

For example, the following JSON formatted trigger configured for a DataNode fires if the DataNode has more than 1500 file-descriptors opened:

[{"triggerName": "sample-trigger",
  "triggerExpression": "IF (SELECT fd_open WHERE roleName=$ROLENAME and last(fd_open) > 1500) DO health:bad",
  "streamThreshold": 0, "enabled": "true"}]

See the trigger rules documentation for more details on how to write triggers using tsquery.

The JSON format is evolving and may change in the future and, as a result, backward compatibility is not guaranteed between releases at this time.

items.displayName: Rules to Extract Events from Log Files
items.description:
This file contains the rules which govern how log messages are turned into events by the custom log4j appender that this role loads. It is in JSON format, and is composed of a list of rules. Every log message is evaluated against each of these rules in turn to decide whether or not to send an event for that message.

Each rule has some or all of the following fields:

  • alert - whether or not events generated from this rule should be promoted to alerts. A value of "true" will cause alerts to be generated. If not specified, the default is "false".
  • rate (mandatory) - the maximum number of log messages matching this rule that may be sent as events every minute. If more than rate matching log messages are received in a single minute, the extra messages are ignored. If rate is less than 0, the number of messages per minute is unlimited.
  • periodminutes - the number of minutes during which the publisher will only publish rate events or fewer. If not specified, the default is one minute
  • threshold - apply this rule only to messages with this log4j severity level or above. An example is "WARN" for warning level messages or higher.
  • content - match only those messages whose contents match this regular expression.
  • exceptiontype - match only those messages which are part of an exception message. The exception type must match this regular expression.

Example:{"alert": false, "rate": 10, "exceptiontype": "java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException"}

This rule will send events to Cloudera Manager for every StringIndexOutOfBoundsException, up to a maximum of 10 every minute.

items.name: oom_heap_dump_dir
items.description: Path to directory where heap dumps are generated when java.lang.OutOfMemoryError error is thrown. This directory is automatically created if it does not exist. If this directory already exists, role user must have write access to this directory. If this directory is shared among multiple roles, it should have 1777 permissions. The heap dump files are created with 600 permissions and are owned by the role user. The amount of free space in this directory should be greater than the maximum Java Process heap size configured for this role.

items.name: hbase_master_executor_openregion_threads
items.description: Number of pooled threads to handle region opening in the master.

items.name: rlimit_fds
items.description: If configured, overrides the process soft and hard rlimits (also called ulimits) for file descriptors to the configured value.

items.name: log4j_safety_valve
items.displayName: Master Logging Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve)
items.description: For advanced use only, a string to be inserted into log4j.properties for this role only.

items.name: max_log_size
items.description: The maximum size, in megabytes, per log file for Master logs.  Typically used by log4j or logback.

items.name: hbase_master_port
items.description: The port that the HBase Master binds to.

items.name: unexpected_exits_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for unexpected exits encountered within a recent period specified by the unexpected_exits_window configuration for the role.

items.name: master_gc_duration_window
items.description: The period to review when computing the moving average of garbage collection time.

items.name: stacks_collection_frequency
items.description: The frequency with which stacks are collected.

items.name: log_directory_free_space_percentage_thresholds
items.displayName: Log Directory Free Space Monitoring Percentage Thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for monitoring of free space on the filesystem that contains this role's log directory. Specified as a percentage of the capacity on that filesystem. This setting is not used if a Log Directory Free Space Monitoring Absolute Thresholds setting is configured.

items.name: master_startup_tolerance
items.description: The amount of time allowed after this role is started that failures of health checks that rely on communication with this role will be tolerated.

items.name: log_directory_free_space_absolute_thresholds
items.displayName: Log Directory Free Space Monitoring Absolute Thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for monitoring of free space on the filesystem that contains this role's log directory.

items.name: oom_heap_dump_enabled
items.displayName: Dump Heap When Out of Memory
items.description: When set, generates heap dump file when java.lang.OutOfMemoryError is thrown.

items.name: master_web_metric_collection_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds on the duration of the metrics request to the web server.

items.name: max_log_backup_index
items.description: The maximum number of rolled log files to keep for Master logs.  Typically used by log4j or logback.

items.name: hbase_master_executor_closeregion_threads
items.description: Number of pooled threads to handle region closing in the master.

items.name: hbase_master_dns_nameserver
items.description: The host name or IP address of the DNS name server which an HBase Master should use to determine the host name used for communication and display purposes.

items.name: hbase_master_logcleaner_plugins
items.description: A comma-separated list of LogCleanerDelegate(s) that are used in LogsCleaner. WAL/HLog cleaner(s) are called in order, so put the log cleaner that prunes the most log files in the front. To implement your own LogCleanerDelegate, add it to HBase's classpath and add the fully-qualified class name here. You should always add the above default log cleaners in the list, unless you have a special reason not to.

items.name: heap_dump_directory_free_space_percentage_thresholds
items.displayName: Heap Dump Directory Free Space Monitoring Percentage Thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for monitoring of free space on the filesystem that contains this role's heap dump directory. Specified as a percentage of the capacity on that filesystem. This setting is not used if a Heap Dump Directory Free Space Monitoring Absolute Thresholds setting is configured.

items.name: unexpected_exits_window
items.description: The period to review when computing unexpected exits.

items.name: hbase_metrics_extended_period
items.description: Time period in seconds to reset long-running metrics (e.g. compactions). This is an HBase specific configuration.

items.name: stacks_collection_method
items.description: The method used to collect stacks. The jstack option involves periodically running the jstack command against the role's daemon process. The servlet method is available for those roles that have an HTTP server endpoint exposing the current stacks traces of all threads. When the servlet method is selected, that HTTP endpoint is periodically scraped.

items.name: oom_sigkill_enabled
items.description: When set, a SIGKILL signal is sent to the role process when java.lang.OutOfMemoryError is thrown.

items.name: master_gc_duration_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for the weighted average time spent in Java garbage collection. Specified as a percentage of elapsed wall clock time.

items.name: rm_memory_hard_limit
items.description: Hard memory limit to assign to this role, enforced by the Linux kernel. When the limit is reached, the kernel will reclaim pages charged to the process. If reclaiming fails, the kernel may kill the process. Both anonymous as well as page cache pages contribute to the limit. Use a value of -1 B to specify no limit. By default processes not managed by Cloudera Manager will have no limit.

items.name: rm_cpu_shares
items.description: Number of CPU shares to assign to this role. The greater the number of shares, the larger the share of the host's CPUs that will be given to this role when the host experiences CPU contention. Must be between 2 and 262144. Defaults to 1024 for processes not managed by Cloudera Manager.

items.name: master_fd_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds of the number of file descriptors used. Specified as a percentage of file descriptor limit.

items.name: stacks_collection_directory
items.description: The directory in which stacks logs are placed. If not set, stacks are logged into a stacks subdirectory of the role's log directory.

items.name: heap_dump_directory_free_space_absolute_thresholds
items.displayName: Heap Dump Directory Free Space Monitoring Absolute Thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for monitoring of free space on the filesystem that contains this role's heap dump directory.

items.name: master_host_health_enabled
items.description: When computing the overall Master health, consider the host's health.

items.name: rm_io_weight
items.description: Weight for the read I/O requests issued by this role. The greater the weight, the higher the priority of the requests when the host experiences I/O contention. Must be between 100 and 1000. Defaults to 1000 for processes not managed by Cloudera Manager.

items.name: master_canary_health_enabled
items.description: Enables the health test that a client can connect to the HBase Master

items.name: hadoop_metrics2_safety_valve
items.displayName: Hadoop Metrics2 Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve)
items.description: Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for Hadoop Metrics2. Properties will be inserted into hadoop-metrics2.properties.

items.name: hbase_master_info_port
items.description: The port for the HBase Master web UI. Set to -1 to disable the HBase Master web UI.

items.name: hbase_master_dns_interface
items.description: The name of the DNS network interface from which an HBase Master should report its IP address.

items.name: hbase_master_bind_to_wildcard_address
items.displayName: HBase Master Bind to Wildcard Address
items.description: When true, HBase Master will bind to 0.0.0.0. Only available with CDH 4.3 and later.

items.name: hbase_master_handler_count
items.description: Number of RPC Server instances spun up on HBase Master.

items.name: MASTER_role_env_safety_valve
items.displayName: Master Environment Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve)
items.description: For advanced use only, key-value pairs (one on each line) to be inserted into a role's environment. Applies to configurations of this role except client configuration.

items.name: enable_config_alerts
items.description: When set, Cloudera Manager will send alerts when this entity's configuration changes.

items.name: hbase_master_java_opts
items.displayName: Java Configuration Options for HBase Master
items.description: These arguments will be passed as part of the Java command line. Commonly, garbage collection flags or extra debugging flags would be passed here.

items.name: role_triggers
items.description:
The configured triggers for this role. This is a JSON formatted list of triggers. These triggers are evaluated as part as the health system. Every trigger expression is parsed, and if the trigger condition is met, the list of actions provided in the trigger expression is executed.

Each trigger has all of the following fields:

  • triggerName (mandatory) - The name of the trigger. This value must be unique for the specific role.
  • triggerExpression (mandatory) - A tsquery expression representing the trigger.
  • streamThreshold (optional) - The maximum number of streams that can satisfy a condition of a trigger before the condition fires. By default set to 0, and any stream returned causes the condition to fire.
  • enabled (optional) - By default set to 'true'. If set to 'false', the trigger will not be evaluated.
  • expressionEditorConfig (optional) - Metadata for the trigger editor. If present, the trigger should only be edited from the Edit Trigger page; editing the trigger here may lead to inconsistencies.

For example, the following JSON formatted trigger configured for a DataNode fires if the DataNode has more than 1500 file-descriptors opened:

[{"triggerName": "sample-trigger",
  "triggerExpression": "IF (SELECT fd_open WHERE roleName=$ROLENAME and last(fd_open) > 1500) DO health:bad",
  "streamThreshold": 0, "enabled": "true"}]

See the trigger rules documentation for more details on how to write triggers using tsquery.

The JSON format is evolving and may change in the future and, as a result, backward compatibility is not guaranteed between releases at this time.

items.name: process_swap_memory_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds on the swap memory usage of the process.

items.name: hbase_master_executor_serverops_threads
items.description: Number of pooled threads to handle the recovery of the region servers in the master.

items.name: hbase_master_info_bindAddress
items.description: The address for the HBase Master web UI

items.name: hbase_regionserver_java_heapsize
items.displayName: Java Heap Size of HBase RegionServer in Bytes
items.description: Maximum size in bytes for the Java Process heap memory.  Passed to Java -Xmx.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_bind_to_wildcard_address
items.displayName: HBase RegionServer Bind to Wildcard Address
items.description: When true, HBase RegionServer will bind to 0.0.0.0. Only available in CDH 4.3 and later.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_optionallogflushinterval
items.description: Sync the HLog to HDFS after this interval, in milliseconds, if it has not accumulated the number of HLog Entries specified to trigger a sync.

items.name: log_threshold
items.description: The minimum log level for RegionServer logs

items.name: hbase_regionserver_handler_count
items.description: Number of RPC Server instances spun up on RegionServers.

items.name: enable_alerts
items.displayName: Enable Health Alerts for this Role
items.description: When set, Cloudera Manager will send alerts when the health of this role reaches the threshold specified by the EventServer setting eventserver_health_events_alert_threshold

items.name: hbase_regionserver_maxlogs
items.displayName: Maximum number of Write-Ahead Log (WAL) files
items.description: Maximum number of Write-Ahead Log (WAL) files. This value multiplied by HDFS Block Size (dfs.blocksize) is the size of the WAL that will need to be replayed when a server crashes. This value is inversely proportional to the frequency of flushes to disk.

items.name: rm_memory_soft_limit
items.description: Soft memory limit to assign to this role, enforced by the Linux kernel. When the limit is reached, the kernel will reclaim pages charged to the process if and only if the host is facing memory pressure. If reclaiming fails, the kernel may kill the process. Both anonymous as well as page cache pages contribute to the limit. Use a value of -1 B to specify no limit. By default processes not managed by Cloudera Manager will have no limit.

items.name: regionserver_memstore_size_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds of the total size of RegionServer's memstores. Specified as a percentage of the configured upper limit. See Maximum Size of All Memstores in RegionServer.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_msginterval
items.description: Interval, in milliseconds, between messages from the RegionServer to the HBase Master. Use a high value such as 3000 for clusters that have more than 10 hosts.

items.name: oom_sigkill_enabled
items.description: When set, a SIGKILL signal is sent to the role process when java.lang.OutOfMemoryError is thrown.

items.name: rm_cpu_shares
items.description: Number of CPU shares to assign to this role. The greater the number of shares, the larger the share of the host's CPUs that will be given to this role when the host experiences CPU contention. Must be between 2 and 262144. Defaults to 1024 for processes not managed by Cloudera Manager.

items.name: hbase_hstore_blockingWaitTime
items.description: The period of time that an HRegion will block updates after reaching the HStoreFile limit that is specified by 'hbase.hstore.blockingStoreFiles'. After this time has elapsed, the HRegion will stop blocking updates even if a compaction has not been completed.

items.name: stacks_collection_directory
items.description: The directory in which stacks logs are placed. If not set, stacks are logged into a stacks subdirectory of the role's log directory.

items.name: hbase_hregion_memstore_mslab_chunksize
items.displayName: Chunk Size Allocated by MSLAB Allocation Scheme
items.description: The size of the chunks allocated by MSLAB, in bytes.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_config_safety_valve
items.displayName: RegionServer Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for hbase-site.xml
items.description: For advanced use only, a string to be inserted into hbase-site.xml for this role only.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_canary_interval
items.description: Duration between consecutive checks done by the Canary.

items.name: hbase_hregion_memstore_block_multiplier
items.description: Blocks writes if the size of the memstore increases to the value of 'hbase.hregion.block.memstore' multiplied by the value of 'hbase.hregion.flush.size' bytes. This setting is useful for preventing runaway memstore during spikes in update traffic. Without an upper-bound, memstore fills such that when it flushes, the resultant process of flushing files take a long time to compact or split, or worse, an "out of memory" error occurs.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_lease_period
items.description: The lease period, in milliseconds, for the HBase RegionServer. Clients must report in within this period or else they are considered dead.

items.name: process_swap_memory_thresholds

items.name: hbase_regionserver_class
items.description: An interface that is assignable to HRegionInterface. Used in HBase Client for opening a proxy to a remote HBase RegionServer.

items.name: regionserver_store_file_idx_size_thresholds
items.displayName: Percentage of Heap Used by HStoreFile Index
items.description: The health test thresholds of the size used by the HStoreFile index. Specified as a percentage of the total heap size.

items.name: regionserver_compaction_queue_window
items.displayName: HBase RegionServer Compaction Queue Monitoring Period
items.description: The period over which to compute the moving average of the compaction queue size.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_hlog_reader_impl
items.description: The HLog file reader implementation.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_regionmover_thread_count
items.description: Number of threads to use while loading and unloading regions to or from a RegionServer. Can be used to increase the speed of decommissioning or rolling restart operations.

items.name: stacks_collection_data_retention
items.description: The amount of stacks data that is retained. After the retention limit is reached, the oldest data is deleted.

items.name: hbase_hregion_memstore_flush_size
items.description: Memstore will be flushed to disk if size of the memstore exceeds this value in number of bytes. This value is checked by a thread that runs the frequency specified by hbase.server.thread.wakefrequency.

items.name: regionserver_read_latency_window
items.displayName: HBase RegionServer HDFS Read Latency Monitoring Period
items.description: The period over which to compute the moving average of the HDFS read latency of the HBase RegionServer.

items.name: regionserver_sync_latency_window
items.displayName: HBase RegionServer HDFS Sync Latency Monitoring Period
items.description: The period over which to compute the moving average of the HDFS sync latency of the HBase RegionServer.

items.description: The host name or IP address of the DNS name server which a RegionServer should use to determine the host name used by the HBase Master for communication and display purposes.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_wal_pipelines
items.description: When using MultiWAL as the WALProvider, sets how many write-ahead-logs each region server should run. Will result in this number of HDFS pipelines. Writes for a given Region only go to a single pipeline, spreading total RegionServer load.

items.name: process_auto_restart
items.description: When set, this role's process is automatically (and transparently) restarted in the event of an unexpected failure.

items.name: hbase_hregion_majorcompaction
items.description: The time, in milliseconds, between 'major' compactions of all HStoreFiles in a region. To disable automated major compactions, set this value to 0.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_codecs
items.description: Comma-separated list of codecs that the RegionServer requires to start. Use this setting to make sure that all RegionServers joining a cluster are installed with a particular set of codecs.

items.name: hbase_hregion_memstore_mslab_max_allocation
items.displayName: Maximum Byte Array from MSLAB Allocation Scheme
items.description: The maximum size byte array that should come from the MSLAB, in bytes.

items.name: hbase_hstore_compactionThreshold
items.description: If this number of HStoreFiles in any one HStore is exceeded, then a compaction is run to rewrite all HStoreFiles files as one HStoreFile. (One HStoreFile is written per flush of memstore.) You can delay compaction by specifying a larger number, but the compaction will take longer when it does run. During a compaction, updates cannot be flushed to disk. Long compactions require memory sufficient to carry the logging of all updates across the duration of the compaction. If too large, clients timeout during compaction.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_wal_provider
items.description: The implementation that should be used by the RegionServer for the write-ahead-log.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_info_port
items.description: The port for the HBase RegionServer web UI. Set to -1 to disable RegionServer web UI.

items.name: regionserver_master_connectivity_enabled
items.displayName: HBase RegionServer to Master Connectivity Test
items.description: Enables the health test that the RegionServer is connected to the Master

items.name: hbase_hstore_blockingStoreFiles
items.description: If there are more than this number of HStoreFiles in any one HStore, then updates are blocked for this HRegion until a compaction is completed, or until the value specified for 'hbase.hstore.blockingWaitTime' has been exceeded.

items.name: hbase_hregion_preclose_flush_size
items.description: If the memstores in a region are this size or larger when closing, run a pre-flush process to clear out memstores before putting up the region closed flag and taking the region offline. On close, a flush process is run under the close flag up to empty memory. During this time, the region is offline and no writes are taken. If the memstore content is large, the flush process could take a long time to complete. The pre-flush process cleans out the bulk of the memstore before putting up the close flag and taking the region offline, so that the flush process that runs under the close flag has little to do.

items.name: regionserver_fd_thresholds

items.name: hbase_regionserver_nbreservationblocks

items.name: log_directory_free_space_absolute_thresholds

items.description: The health test thresholds for monitoring of free space on the filesystem that contains this role's log directory.

items.name: oom_heap_dump_enabled

items.name: regionserver_sync_latency_thresholds

items.description: The health test thresholds for the latency of HDFS write operations that the RegionServer detects

items.name: unexpected_exits_window

items.name: hbase_regionserver_global_memstore_upperLimit

items.name: hbase_regionserver_hlog_writer_impl
items.description: The HLog file writer implementation.

items.name: regionserver_flush_queue_window
items.displayName: HBase RegionServer Flush Queue Monitoring Period
items.description: The period over which to compute the moving average of the flush queue size.

items.name: hbase_hstore_compaction_max

items.name: regionserver_gc_duration_thresholds

items.name: hbase_regionserver_global_memstore_lowerLimit
items.description: When memstores are being forced to flush to make room in memory, keep flushing until this amount is reached. If this amount is equal to 'hbase.regionserver.global.memstore.upperLimit', then minimum possible flushing will occur when updates are blocked due to memstore limiting.

items.name: rm_memory_hard_limit
items.description: Hard memory limit to assign to this role, enforced by the Linux kernel. When the limit is reached, the kernel will reclaim pages charged to the process. If reclaiming fails, the kernel may kill the process. Both anonymous as well as page cache pages contribute to the limit. Use a value of -1 B to specify no limit. By default processes not managed by Cloudera Manager will have no limit.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_port
items.description: The port that an HBase RegionServer binds to.

items.name: heap_dump_directory_free_space_absolute_thresholds
items.displayName: Heap Dump Directory Free Space Monitoring Absolute Thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds for monitoring of free space on the filesystem that contains this role's heap dump directory.

items.name: hbase_hash_type
items.description: The hashing algorithm for use in HashFunction. Two values are supported: 'murmur' (for MurmurHash) and 'jenkins' (for JenkinsHash).

items.name: rm_io_weight
items.description: Weight for the read I/O requests issued by this role. The greater the weight, the higher the priority of the requests when the host experiences I/O contention. Must be between 100 and 1000. Defaults to 1000 for processes not managed by Cloudera Manager.

items.name: hadoop_metrics2_safety_valve

items.name: enable_config_alerts
items.description: When set, Cloudera Manager will send alerts when this entity's configuration changes.

items.name: hbase_coprocessor_region_classes
items.description: List of coprocessors that are loaded by default on all tables. For any override coprocessor method, these classes will be called in order. After implementing your own coprocessor, just put it in HBase's classpath and add the fully qualified class name here. A coprocessor can also be loaded on demand by setting HTableDescriptor.

items.name: role_triggers
items.description:
The configured triggers for this role. This is a JSON formatted list of triggers. These triggers are evaluated as part as the health system. Every trigger expression is parsed, and if the trigger condition is met, the list of actions provided in the trigger expression is executed.

Each trigger has all of the following fields:

  • triggerName (mandatory) - The name of the trigger. This value must be unique for the specific role.
  • triggerExpression (mandatory) - A tsquery expression representing the trigger.
  • streamThreshold (optional) - The maximum number of streams that can satisfy a condition of a trigger before the condition fires. By default set to 0, and any stream returned causes the condition to fire.
  • enabled (optional) - By default set to 'true'. If set to 'false', the trigger will not be evaluated.
  • expressionEditorConfig (optional) - Metadata for the trigger editor. If present, the trigger should only be edited from the Edit Trigger page; editing the trigger here may lead to inconsistencies.

For example, the following JSON formatted trigger configured for a DataNode fires if the DataNode has more than 1500 file-descriptors opened:

[{"triggerName": "sample-trigger",
  "triggerExpression": "IF (SELECT fd_open WHERE roleName=$ROLENAME and last(fd_open) > 1500) DO health:bad",
  "streamThreshold": 0, "enabled": "true"}]

See the trigger rules documentation for more details on how to write triggers using tsquery.

The JSON format is evolving and may change in the future and, as a result, backward compatibility is not guaranteed between releases at this time.

items.name: regionserver_web_metric_collection_enabled
items.description: Enables the health test that the Cloudera Manager Agent can successfully contact and gather metrics from the web server.

items.name: hdfs_service
items.description: Name of the HDFS service that this HBase service instance depends on

items.name: zookeeper_service
items.description: Name of the ZooKeeper service that this HBase service instance depends on.

items.name: zookeeper_znode_rootserver

items.name: hbase_hbck_poller_enabled
items.description: Enables the HBase Hbck Poller so that Hbck reports will be available. Enabling the Hbck poller will increase the amount of memory used by the Service Monitor. Consider increasing the Service Monitor Java heap size by an additional 3KB per region. For example, for a cluster with 10,000 regions, increase the JVM heap size by approximately 30MB.

items.name: hbase_snapshot_master_timeout_millis

items.name: audit_event_log_dir

items.name: zookeeper_pause

items.name: hbase_security_authorization
items.description: Enable HBase authorization.

items.name: dfs_client_read_shortcircuit
items.description: Enable HDFS short circuit read. This allows a client co-located with the DataNode to read HDFS file blocks directly. This gives a performance boost to distributed clients that are aware of locality.

items.name: smon_derived_configs_safety_valve

items.description: Name of the scheduler pool to use for MR jobs created during export/import of remote snapshots in AWS S3.

items.name: zookeeper_session_timeout
items.description: ZooKeeper session timeout in milliseconds. HBase passes this to the ZooKeeper quorum as the suggested maximum time for a session. See http://hadoop.apache.org/zookeeper/docs/current/zookeeperProgrammers.html#ch_zkSessions The client sends a requested timeout, the server responds with the timeout that it can give the client.
items.validationMessage: ZooKeeper and HBase session timeouts are compatible.

items.name: navigator_event_tracker
items.description:
Configures the rules for event tracking and coalescing. This feature is used to define equivalency between different audit events. When events match, according to a set of configurable parameters, only one entry in the audit list is generated for all the matching events.

Tracking works by keeping a reference to events when they first appear, and comparing other incoming events against the "tracked" events according to the rules defined here.

Event trackers are defined in a JSON object like the following:

{
  "timeToLive" : [integer],
  "fields" : [
    {
      "type" : [string],
      "name" : [string]
    }
  ]
}

Where:

  • timeToLive: maximum amount of time an event will be tracked, in milliseconds. Must be provided. This defines how long, since it's first seen, an event will be tracked. A value of 0 disables tracking.
  • fields: list of fields to compare when matching events against tracked events.

Each field has an evaluator type associated with it. The evaluator defines how the field data is to be compared. The following evaluators are available:

  • value: uses the field value for comparison.
  • username: treats the field value as a user name, and ignores any host-specific data. This is useful for environment using Kerberos, so that only the principal name and realm are compared.

The following is the list of fields that can used to compare HBase events:

  • operation: the HBase operation being performed.
  • username: the user performing the action.
  • ipAddress: the IP from where the request originated.
  • allowed: whether the operation was allowed or denied.
  • tableName: the name of the table affected by the operation.
  • family: the column family affected by the operation.
  • qualifier: the qualifier of the operation.

The default event tracker for HBase services defines equality by comparing the username, operation, table name, family, and qualifier of the events.

items.name: hbase_canary_alert_unhealthy_region_percent_threshold
items.displayName: HBase Canary Unhealthy Region Percentage Alert Threshold
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase region health canary detects at least this percentage of total regions are unhealthy. This threshold is used if the explicit count is not set via the hbase_canary_alert_unhealthy_region_count_threshold config.

items.name: hbase_server_dfs_client_hedged_read_threadpool_size
items.description: Size of the threadpool used for hedged reads in hdfs clients. If a read from a block is slow, a parallel 'hedged' read will be started against a different block replica. The first one to return with a result is used while the other one is cancelled. This 'hedged' read feature helps rein in the outliers. A value of zero disables the feature.

items.name: hbase_restserver_security_authentication

items.name: hbase_user_to_impersonate
items.description: The user the management services impersonate when connecting to HBase. If no value is specified, the HBase superuser is used.

items.name: enable_alerts

items.name: hbase_ssl_server_safety_valve
items.displayName: HBase Service Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for ssl-server.xml
items.description: For advanced use only, a string to be inserted into ssl-server.xml. Applies to configurations of all roles in this service except client configuration.

items.name: hbase_replication_source_nb_capacity
items.description: Maximum number of hlog entries to replicate in one go. If this is large, and a consumer takes a while to process the events, the HBase RPC call will time out.

items.name: hbase_enable_replication
items.description: Allow HBase tables to be replicated.

items.name: hbase_service_config_safety_valve
items.displayName: HBase Service Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for hbase-site.xml
items.description: For advanced use only, a string to be inserted into hbase-site.xml. Applies to configurations of all roles in this service except client configuration.

items.name: hbase_region_health_canary_exclude_tables
items.displayName: HBase Region Health Canary Exclude Tables
items.description: Tables to exclude in the HBase Region Health Canary which will scan a row from every region.

items.name: navigator_audit_enabled
items.description: Enable collection of audit events from the service's roles.

items.name: hbase_client_write_buffer
items.description: Write buffer size in bytes. A larger buffer requires more memory on both the client and the server because the server instantiates the passed write buffer to process it but reduces the number of remote procedure calls (RPC). To estimate the amount of server memory used, multiply the value of 'hbase.client.write.buffer' by the value of 'hbase.regionserver.handler.count'.

items.name: service_triggers
items.description:
The configured triggers for this service. This is a JSON formatted list of triggers. These triggers are evaluated as part as the health system. Every trigger expression is parsed, and if the trigger condition is met, the list of actions provided in the trigger expression is executed.

Each trigger has all of the following fields:

  • triggerName (mandatory) - The name of the trigger. This value must be unique for the specific service.
  • triggerExpression (mandatory) - A tsquery expression representing the trigger.
  • streamThreshold (optional) - The maximum number of streams that can satisfy a condition of a trigger before the condition fires. By default set to 0, and any stream returned causes the condition to fire.
  • enabled (optional) - By default set to 'true'. If set to 'false', the trigger will not be evaluated.
  • expressionEditorConfig (optional) - Metadata for the trigger editor. If present, the trigger should only be edited from the Edit Trigger page; editing the trigger here may lead to inconsistencies.

For example, the followig JSON formatted trigger fires if there are more than 10 DataNodes with more than 500 file-descriptors opened:

[{"triggerName": "sample-trigger",
  "triggerExpression": "IF (SELECT fd_open WHERE roleType = DataNode and last(fd_open) > 500) DO health:bad",
  "streamThreshold": 10, "enabled": "true"}]

See the trigger rules documentation for more details on how to write triggers using tsquery.

The JSON format is evolving and may change in the future and, as a result, backward compatibility is not guaranteed between releases at this time.

items.name: navigator_audit_event_filter
items.description:
Event filters are defined in a JSON object like the following: 

{
  "defaultAction" : ("accept", "discard"),
  "rules" : [
    {
      "action" : ("accept", "discard"),
      "fields" : [
        {
          "name" : "fieldName",
          "match" : "regex"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

A filter has a default action and a list of rules, in order of precedence. Each rule defines an action, and a list of fields to match against the audit event.

A rule is "accepted" if all the listed field entries match the audit event. At that point, the action declared by the rule is taken.

If no rules match the event, the default action is taken. Actions default to "accept" if not defined in the JSON object.

The following is the list of fields that can be filtered for HBase events:

  • allowed: whether the operation was allowed or denied.
  • username: the user performing the action.
  • tableName: the table affected by the operation.
  • family: the column family affected by the operation.
  • qualifier: the qualifier the operation.
  • action: the action being performed.

The default HBase audit event filter discards events that affect the internal -ROOT-, .META. and _acl_ tables.

This option prevents a region from splitting if the data is too large. Set this option to a fraction of the maximum region size. To disable this check, use a value of zero or less.

To disable entirely, use a string that does not correspond to a group name, such as '_no_group_'. Note: This property is used only if HBase REST/Thrift Server Authentication is enabled.

items.name: hbase_hbck_poller_check_hdfs
items.description: Configures whether the Hbck poller checks HDFS or not. Checking HBase tables and regions information on HDFS can take a while.

items.name: hbase_master_health_enabled

items.displayName: Amazon S3 Path for Remote Snapshots

items.name: hbase_thriftserver_security_authentication
items.description: If this is set, HBase Thrift Server authenticates its clients. HBase Proxy User Hosts and Groups should be configured to allow specific users to access HBase through Thrift Server.

items.name: hbase_security_authentication
items.description: Choose the authentication mechanism used by HBase.

items.name: navigator_audit_log_max_file_size
items.description: Maximum size of audit log file in MB before it is rolled over.

items.name: hbase_service_env_safety_valve
items.displayName: HBase Service Environment Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve)
items.description: For advanced use only, key-value pairs (one on each line) to be inserted into a role's environment. Applies to configurations of all roles in this service except client configuration.

items.name: hbase_replication_source_ratio
items.description: Ratio of Lily HBase Indexers used by each HBase RegionServer while doing replication.

items.name: zookeeper_znode_parent
items.description: The root znode for HBase in ZooKeeper. All of HBase's ZooKeeper files that are configured with a relative path will go under this node. By default, all of HBase's ZooKeeper file paths are configured with a relative path, so they will all go under this directory unless changed.

items.name: navigator_client_config_safety_valve
items.displayName: HBASE Client Advanced Configuration Snippet (Safety Valve) for navigator.client.properties
items.description: For advanced use only, a string to be inserted into the client configuration for navigator.client.properties.

items.name: process_groupname
items.description: The group that this service's processes should run as.

items.name: hbase_client_scanner_caching
items.description: Number of rows to fetch when calling next on a scanner if it is not served from memory. Higher caching values enable faster scanners but require more memory and some calls of next may take longer when the cache is empty.

items.name: hbase_regionservers_healthy_thresholds
items.description: The health test thresholds of the overall RegionServer health. The check returns "Concerning" health if the percentage of "Healthy" RegionServers falls below the warning threshold. The check is unhealthy if the total percentage of "Healthy" and "Concerning" RegionServers falls below the critical threshold.

items.name: smon_client_config_overrides
items.description: For advanced use only, a list of configuration properties that will be used by the Service Monitor instead of the current client configuration for the service.

items.name: hbase_superuser
items.description: List of users or groups, who are allowed full privileges, regardless of stored ACLs, across the cluster. Only used when HBase security is enabled.

items.name: hbase_thriftserver_support_proxyuser
items.description: Use this to allow proxy users on thrift gateway, which is mainly needed for "doAs" functionality.

items.name: hbase_backup_masters_health_enabled
items.description: When computing the overall HBase cluster health, consider the health of the backup HBase Masters.

items.name: hbase_client_pause
items.description: A general client pause time value. Used mostly as a time period to wait before retrying operations such as a failed get or region lookup.

items.name: hbase_client_retries_number
items.description: Maximum number of client retries. Used as a maximum for all operations such as fetching of the root region from the root RegionServer, getting a cell's value, and starting a row update.

items.name: navigator_audit_queue_policy
items.description: Action to take when the audit event queue is full. Drop the event or shutdown the affected process.

items.name: hbase_regionserver_enable_canary
items.description: Start a process to periodically check that RegionServer is alive when RegionServer is started. Note: This canary is different from the Cloudera Service Monitoring canary and is provided by the HBase service itself.

items.name: hbase_snapshot_region_timeout
items.description: The maximum amount of time the Hbase RegionServer waits for a snapshot to complete.

items.name: hbase_secure_rpc_engine
items.description: Set to true to use HBase Secure RPC Engine for remote procedure calls (RPC). This is only effective in simple authentication mode. Does not provide authentication for RPC calls, but provides user information in the audit logs.  Changing this setting requires a restart of this and all dependent services and redeployment of client configurations, along with a restart of the Service Monitor management role.

items.name: hbase_proxy_user_hosts_list
items.description: Comma-delimited list of hosts where you want to allow the HBase user to impersonate other users. The default '*' allows all hosts. To disable entirely, use a string that does not correspond to a host name, such as '_no_host'. Note: This property is used only if HBase REST/Thrift Server Authentication is enabled.

items.name: hdfs_rootdir
items.description: The HDFS directory shared by HBase RegionServers.
items.validationMessage: The value /hbase for HDFS Root Directory is not being used elsewhere.

items.name: hbase_enable_indexing
items.description: Allow indexing of tables in HBase by Lily HBase Indexer. Note: Replication must be enabled for indexing to work.

items.name: hbase_hbck_alert_region_error_count_threshold
items.displayName: HBase Hbck Region Error Count Alert Threshold
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase Hbck tool detects at least this many regions with errors across all tables in this service. If the value is not set, alerts will not be published based on the count of regions with errors.

items.name: ssl_server_keystore_keypassword
items.description: Password that protects the private key contained in the server keystore used for encrypted web UIs.

items.name: hbase_region_health_canary_slow_run_alert_enabled
items.displayName: HBase Region Health Canary Slow Run Alert Enabled
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase region health canary runs slowly.

items.name: hbase_server_thread_wakefrequency
items.description: Period of time, in milliseconds, to pause between searches for work. Used as a sleep interval by service threads such as a META scanner and log roller.

items.name: hbase_graceful_stop_timeout
items.description: Timeout for graceful shutdown of this HBase service. Once this timeout is reached, any remaining running roles are abruptly shutdown. A value of 0 means no timeout.

items.name: hbase_snapshot_master_timeoutMillis
items.description: The timeout before injecting a snapshot timeout error when waiting for a snapshot completion.

items.name: hbase_snapshot_enabled
items.description: Enable snapshots. Disabling snapshots requires deletion of all snapshots before restarting the HBase master; the HBase master will not start if snapshots are disabled and snapshots exist.

items.name: ssl_server_keystore_location
items.description: Path to the keystore file containing the server certificate and private key used for encrypted web UIs.

items.name: hbase_hbck_slow_run_alert_enabled
items.displayName: HBase Hbck Slow Run Alert Enabled
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase Hbck tool runs slowly.

items.name: hbase_coprocessor_abort_on_error
items.description: Set to true to cause the hosting server (Master or RegionServer) to abort if a coprocessor throws a Throwable object that is not IOException or a subclass of IOException. Setting it to true might be useful in development environments where one wants to terminate the server as soon as possible to simplify coprocessor failure analysis.

items.name: hbase_canary_alert_unhealthy_region_count_threshold
items.displayName: HBase Canary Unhealthy Region Count Alert Threshold
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase region health canary detects at least this many unhealthy regions. This setting takes precedence over the hbase_canary_alert_unhealthy_region_percent_threshold config.

items.name: hbase_snapshot_s3_secret_access_key
items.displayName: AWS S3 Secret Access Key for Remote Snapshots
items.description: AWS secret access key required to access S3 to store remote snapshots.

items.name: hbase_rpc_timeout
items.description: Timeout for all HBase RPCs in milliseconds.

items.name: hbase_hbck_alert_error_codes
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase Hbck tool finds any errors with matching codes. Possible error codes: UNKNOWN, NO_META_REGION, NULL_ROOT_REGION, NO_VERSION_FILE, NOT_IN_META_HDFS, NOT_IN_META, NOT_IN_META_OR_DEPLOYED, NOT_IN_HDFS_OR_DEPLOYED, NOT_IN_HDFS, SERVER_DOES_NOT_MATCH_META, NOT_DEPLOYED, MULTI_DEPLOYED, SHOULD_NOT_BE_DEPLOYED, MULTI_META_REGION, RS_CONNECT_FAILURE, FIRST_REGION_STARTKEY_NOT_EMPTY, LAST_REGION_ENDKEY_NOT_EMPTY, DUPE_STARTKEYS, HOLE_IN_REGION_CHAIN, OVERLAP_IN_REGION_CHAIN, REGION_CYCLE, DEGENERATE_REGION, ORPHAN_HDFS_REGION, LINGERING_SPLIT_PARENT, NO_TABLEINFO_FILE

items.name: hbase_active_master_detecton_window
items.description: The tolerance window that will be used in HBase service tests that depend on detection of the active HBase Master.

items.name: process_username
items.description: The user that this service's processes should run as.

items.name: hbase_snapshot_s3_access_key_id
items.displayName: Amazon S3 Access Key ID for Remote Snapshots
items.description: Access key ID required to access Amazon S3 to store remote snapshots.

items.name: enable_config_alerts
items.description: When set, Cloudera Manager will send alerts when this entity's configuration changes.

items.name: zookeeper_retries
items.description: The number of times to retry connections to ZooKeeper. Used for reading and writing root region location. Used together with ${zookeeper.pause} in an exponential backoff fashion when making queries to ZooKeeper.

items.name: hbase_region_health_canary_enabled
items.description: Enables the canary that checks HBase region availability by scanning a row from every region.

items.name: ssl_server_keystore_password
items.description: Password for the server keystore file used for encrypted web UIs.

items.name: hbase_hbck_alert_error_count_threshold
items.displayName: HBase Hbck Error Count Alert Threshold
items.description: An alert is published if the HBase Hbck tool detects at least this many errors across all tables in this service. Some errors are not associated with a region, e.g. 'RS_CONNECT_FAILURE'. If the value is not set, alerts will not be published based on the count of errors.

items.name: hbase_hbck_poller_max_error_count
items.displayName: HBase Hbck Poller Maximum Error Count
items.description: Maximum number of errors that the HBase Hbck poller will retain through a given run

items.name: hbase_hadoop_ssl_enabled
items.description: Enable SSL encryption for HBase web UIs.

items.name: log_event_retry_frequency
items.description: The frequency in which the log4j event publication appender will retry sending undelivered log events to the Event server, in seconds
